form.label: OMB M-21-31 - General Usage
form.description: Describes how to use this app for tracking OMB M-21-31 compliance progress.

span.p: These aren't necessarily needed for tracking compliance with this app. One or two dashboards or panels may not work without the "Network Diagram Viz", but neither of these apps are technically needed for the basic functionality of this app to be available. They either make a task a little easier or grant the ability to use advanced functionality within this app (e.g., the Gap Analysis dashboard)

ol.li: Splunk App for Lookup File Editing (aka "Lookup Editor") - For easily updating lookups within the Splunk UI

span.p: Using this App for Tracking M-21-31 Compliance

ul.li: Visit the Getting Started dashboard. Answer the questions and following the instructions to create the lookup that will be used for tracking compliance progress. If tracking for multiple groups, then please see the Multi-Tenant Metrics section below.
Meet with leadership and determine which M-21-31 checks are not relevant to the organization.

ol.li: It's recommended to use the Search Memo dashboard for quickly filtering through the memo.

During the assessment, don't try and update the status lookup via the "Splunk App for Lookup File Editing" (aka "Lookup Editor") app. I highly recommend using something different (e.g., VS Code, Notepad++, Onenote, Excel, etc.) for quickly taking notes on which ones are irrelevant. As of this writing (2024-05), the Lookup Editor still lacks certain functionality that would make it much faster/easier to use. We need speed, and that app allows for everything but that. Update the lookup however you want afterwards. I started working on a dashboard for optimizing this process, but the juice wasn't worth the squeeze.

When updating a check's relevancy in the status lookup, determine the check ids for the ones that are not relevant and then update the check-is_relevant field with the appropriate value (see Lookup Reference for allowed values).
It is highly recommended to have documentation of leadership's approval of which checks were marked as irrelevant and why. Someone will ask about it (e.g., onboarding, auditors, etc.).
Feel free to add more fields to the status lookup, as needed. Afterwards, they will be available for reference in the dashboards via the "Search Query/Keyword Filter" text input.

ul.li: Meet with the admins and/or users that know the most about what data exists in the environment.
Read through the checks in the lookup omb-m2131.

In the lookup omb-m2131-status, update the fields coverage-data_collection_status and coverage-data_in_siem with one of the allowed values. More info on the allowed values can be seen in the "Lookups" section of this dashboard.
coverage-data_collection_status: Are you collecting ALL data for this check?
IF and ONLY IF you're collecting 100% of the data for the check, then set it to "Y" or "Yes".
If you're not 100% confident that you're collecting all of the data for this check, but you know you're collecting at least something for it, then set it to "P" or "Partial".
If the check is relevant and you're not collecting anything for the check, then set it to "N" or "No".
If you're not sure and need to come back to it, then just set it to "?" or "Unknown" so everyone knows it's at least been visited and then come back to it later.
coverage-data_in_siem: Is the data available in the SIEM?
"P" and "Partial" are not valid values here. Either it's available, it's not available, or you don't know. There's no middle ground here.
This should only be set to "Y" or "Yes" if coverage-data_collection_status is set to "Y", "Yes", "P", or "Partial"; otherwise, it wouldn't make sense.
If it's not being collected in the SIEM, but IS being collected somewhere else and can be pulled into the SIEM, then you can optionally set coverage-data_exists_elsewhere to "Y" or "Yes". It won't really affect the score, but it's good documentation practices. I'd also recommend adding something in the coverage-notes field to indicate where it is located, because people will definitely ask about it.

If tracking compliance for multiple groups, then the lookup that will need to be updated should be called omb-m2131-status-<GROUP_NAME>, unless it was changed or a different suffix was provided when the lookup was created.

ol.li: For now, it's recommended to perform this phase via the "Splunk App for Lookup File Editing" (aka "Lookup Editor") app.
If an average of 30 seconds or more is spent on each check, then the assessors should re-evaluate their current approach.

Try to avoid wasting the SME's time. Here are some ways to help prevent that from happening.
Ignore adding Splunk queries during this phase. This is meant to be a semi-fast phase. Documenting queries should be reserved for Phase 3.
Only focus on updating the fields mentioned above in the "Action Items" section, unless Phase 3 will be performed and the items being added are important for the those performing it. For example,
If the correct POC for a data source is different than who was originally expected, then document the correct POC in the appropriate field.
If the referenced data is a different SIEM, then mark coverage-data_exists_elsewhere with the appropriate value and document the SIEM in the coverage-notes field.
If the check can be interpreted multiple ways, then document the way it's being interpreted in the check-notes field. This WILL come up later during Phase 3, review, or auditing. If the chosen interpretation wasn't documented, then no one will remember it and everyone will look foolish.

ul.li: Fill in the remaining fields in the m2131 status lookup, as appropriate. At a minimum, document a query in the query field for each check.
Mulitple groups/departments in an organization need to be tracked separately, with the analysis results being visible in both a consolidated and individual format.

ol.li:
Visit the Getting Started dashboard and following the instructions.
When complete, it will have created a lookup file that will be used for tracking compliance progress for the specified group. It will also create a lookup definitiona for the lookup file.
It will ask you to specify a display name for the group. This will be automatically used in the label at the top of various dashboards in this app, as well as the name of the lookup file.

Each time a lookup file is created with that dashboard, a lookup definition will also be automatically created that points the lookup file. The lookup definition will have the same name as the lookup file, excluding ".csv".

Additionally, when a new status lookup is created for a group using the , a macro (called `omb-m2131-status-all`) will also be created/updated to include the new lookup definition. This macro prevents a user from having to select the same multiple items ad nauseam, instead allowing them the ability to click a single item that references all groups.

Macro Naming Requirements: A macro can also be manually created that contains a subset of the groups. If the macro is meant to be used in the dashboards in this app, then please follow the guidance below.
The macro's name MUST start with either "omb-m2131-status-" or "m2131-status-", but can end with anything.
The macro's definition MUST have the lookup definitions or lookup files on a single line.
Each lookup reference MUST be delimited by a comma.
One or more spaces MAY be included after commas, if desired
The macro definition MUST only include the following characters: letters, numbers, underscores, periods, dashes, commas, & spaces.
This has a couple of different use cases:
Consistency needs to be ensured for reporting since it prevents users from forgetting to include one or more groups.
There are so many groups that it's annoying selecting them all in the dashboard.
Example: Here's an example of how the macros might be structured in order to track a subset of groups in a larger group that doesn't include data from one or more other groups.
I have groups A, B, C, D, E, & F. I need to track A, B, & C together as one larger group called "alpha", D & E as another larger group called "bravo", & F separately by itself. I may want to create the following macros for easily changing contexts in the dashboards.
Name: m2131-status-alpha
Definition: omb-m2131-status-group_a, omb-m2131-status-group_b, omb-m2131-status-group_c
Name: m2131-status-bravo
Definition: omb-m2131-status-group_d, omb-m2131-status-group_e
Notes:
I'm only including "group_" in the name of the example lookups for ease of understanding. It is not a required naming convention. I could have excluded it to no ill effect.
Since I can already select "group F" by itself using its lookup definition, there would be no need to create a macro for it, unless there's a requirement for consistency.
